Ani.

entry.title: Operating Concern and Controlling Area
entry.content:
Please let me know whether my understanding is correct. If not, I would appreciate guidance on any points I may have misinterpreted.

  1. One operating concern can contain multiple controlling areas.
  2. Operating Concern is the highest organizational unit in profitability analysis. (COPA) 
  3. Controlling Area is the highest organizational unit in Controlling (CO) 
  4. Controlling Area controls internal accounting, cost center accounting, internal orders, product costing, COPA settlement relations.
  5. Operating Concern defines how you want to analyze profitability (market-driven view).
  6. Operating Concern stores revenue, cost of sales, margins, contribution, characteristics, and value fields.
  7. Operating Concern can be mapped to multiple company codes condition all company codes must share same characteristics and values.
  8. Controlling Area can be mapped to multiple company codes condition all company codes must share same FYV and Chart of Account.
  9. Also can we say controlling area is for internal costing and operating concern is for profiability based on marketing and sales against external compnents like products, customers or zones ?

entry.title: FBL1N or FBL5N, the Profit Center field is always blank.
entry.content:
When I open FBL1N or FBL5N, the Profit Center field is always blank.

I understand that this happens because these reports are based on BSEG, which is the entry view. In the entry view, the Profit Center is not stored on the vendor line item.

When I switch to the G/L view, the Profit Center appears correctly with values.

Also, Document Splitting is active and working fine, and the Profit Center is correctly derived on the G/L lines.

entry.title: Migration of Open Items with VAT Codes into SAP S/4HANA with Migration Cockpit
entry.content:
Current Situation

As part of an SAP migration project from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA, open items for customers (AR), vendors (AP), and G/L accounts (balance sheet and P&L) are migrated using the Migration Cockpit with the staging table approach and XML template files.

During this process, it becomes apparent that some open items in the SAP ERP source system contain a VAT (tax) code. However, the migration of these VAT codes is technically limited or problematic, especially when no corresponding tax-relevant G/L line item exists.

Reasons for Not Migrating VAT Codes

The VAT code is currently not migrated for the following reasons:

  1. Closed VAT reporting period in the source system
    The VAT return for the closed period 12/20XX must be executed in the SAP ERP system, as only there all tax-relevant document line items for the final reporting period are fully available.

  2. Technical restrictions of the Migration Cockpit
    The Migration Cockpit (staging table approach) does not appear to support a consistent migration of VAT codes for open items when no tax-relevant G/L line item is transferred together with the customer or vendor line.

Error Message During Migration

When attempting to migrate open items with a VAT code, the following system message occurs:

“Tax code XX is not contained in any G/L account line item”
Message class: FF
Message number: 753

System Diagnosis

The document contains a customer or vendor line item with a VAT code, but no corresponding tax-relevant G/L line item.
Since tax line items are derived from the accounting document, the system considers this an inconsistent posting.

SAP further explains that such postings may lead to:

  • Cash discount bases being set to zero if not entered manually

  • Incorrect or incomplete tax recalculation during cash discount clearing

  • Tax reporting inconsistencies in the target system

Current Technical Workaround

By changing the message control in transaction OBA5, the error can be downgraded to a warning, allowing the open items to be migrated despite the inconsistency.

Open Question and Business Risk

This leads to the central question:

Can automatic tax correction during payment runs (including cash discount calculation) still be performed correctly in SAP S/4HANA if open items are migrated without a tax-relevant G/L line item or without the original VAT code?

If the VAT code is not migrated, this may cause functional limitations in SAP S/4HANA, especially in:

  • Payment runs for customers and vendors

  • Cash discount processing

  • Automatic tax corrections and tax reporting

Key Questions

  • What are the technically and functionally correct approaches to migrate open items with VAT codes from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA?

  • What options does the Migration Cockpit (staging table approach) offer for transferring VAT codes in open items?

  • What are the advantages and disadvantages of each approach
    (e.g. migrating VAT codes vs. deliberately omitting them)?

  • What are the impacts on downstream processes, especially payment runs, cash discount handling, and tax adjustments in SAP S/4HANA?

Objective

The objective is to identify a technically sound, audit-compliant, and process-stable solution for migrating open items with VAT codes that ensures correct financial processing and tax handling in SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: S/4HANA–Does Leading Ledger 0L Require the Same Fiscal Year and Posting Period Variant for All CoCo?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Experts,

I am facing an issue related to the Leading Ledger 0L in SAP S/4HANA, and I would like to clarify the correct concept.

Background:
In ECC, I worked with ledger 0L, where multiple company codes were assigned, and each company code had:

  • Different Fiscal Year Variants (FYV)

  • Different Posting Period Variants (PPV)

This worked without any issue in ECC.

Current Issue in S/4HANA:
In S/4HANA, when I try to maintain or open T-code: FINSC_LEDGER, I get an error related to data inconsistency. I have shared screenshots below.

 

While searching online, I found multiple references stating that:

All company codes assigned to leading ledger 0L must have the same Fiscal Year Variant and Posting Period Variant.

This is confusing to me because it was possible in ECC to have different FYV and PPV under the same leading ledger.

My Questions:

1.   In S/4HANA, is it mandatory that all company codes assigned to the leading ledger 0L must have the same:

  • Fiscal Year Variant?

  • Posting Period Variant?

2.   If yes, why was this restriction introduced in S/4HANA, and how does it technically impact:

  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA)?

  • Cross-company reporting?

3.   How can this error in FINSC_LEDGER be resolved correctly without causing inconsistencies?

I would really appreciate an explanation comparing ECC vs S/4HANA behavior, and best practices for ledger and company code design in S/4HANA.

Thank you in advance for your guidance.

Regards,
Suba

entry.title: Asset Reporting in Test System
entry.content:
Hi there, 

I have a request from a business user to make a change to a standard Asset Report (S_ALR_87011964).

However, when I go to run this report in our test system, I get the following message. 

"Fiscal year change not yet made for company code 1140. Message no. AB059"

Then when I go to transaction AJRW, I get the following message "NOTE: The fiscal year change is only a technical step, needed in order to carry forward all assets into the new fiscal year. The fiscal year change has nothing to do with the YEAR-END CLOSING for bookkeeping. In order to close the annual values in Asset Accounting for a given fiscal year, you are required to carry out YEAR-END CLOSING in Asset Accounting BEFORE the year-end closing for
the general ledger. "

So my question is - is there any short-cut/work-around that can be done to mimic/bypass year end closing in our Test environments? This has not been processed in any of our test system since go-live (10 years ago) so would involve a lot of work now just so that we can test an Asset report.

Thanks,

Avril

Best regards,

dai

entry.title: Fiscal Year Variant Change from 4-4-5 to Calendar Year
entry.content:
Many companies in retail use the 4‑4‑5 fiscal calendar for their financial closing. But sometimes the business decides to move to a calendar year (K4) instead. Changing the fiscal year variant in SAP sounds simple, but it comes with important restrictions and risks.

Why SAP Blocks the Change

SAP puts a hard stop error when you try to change the fiscal year variant if any transactions already exist in the company code. This is because changing the fiscal year structure after postings have happened can create serious issues, such as:

  • Data inconsistency in financial postings

  • Wrong period determination for documents

  • Open items not matching correctly

  • Reporting mismatches across modules

  • Integration failures with connected systems

  • System performance issues during period close

  • Historical data becoming confusing or incorrect

Because of these risks, SAP does not recommend changing the fiscal year variant directly in a live system.

Possible Solutions

There are three ways to handle this situation:

Option 1: Contact SAP Consulting

SAP’s expert team can analyze your system and suggest the safest approach. This is the most controlled option but may take time and cost money.

Option 2: Shorten the Current Fiscal Year

You can “short end” the current fiscal year, create a new fiscal year variant based on the calendar year, and assign it to the company code. This approach is more complex and may not fit all business scenarios.

Option 3: Change the Variant from 4‑4‑5 to K4 and Test End‑to‑End

This is the most practical option for this scenario. You change the fiscal year variant directly and then perform full testing to ensure nothing breaks.

We will proceed with Option 3.

How to Change the Fiscal Year Variant

  1. Go to OB37 and try to change the fiscal year variant assignment.

     

     

  2. You will see this error message: “Check if postings already exist in Co.Code XXXX / Ledger 0L!”

     

     

    This is SAP’s hard stop.

  3. To continue, convert this error into a warning:

    • SPRO → Financial Accounting → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Tools → Change Message Control

    • Application Area: FINS_ACDOC_CUST

    • Message Number: 116

    • Change it from Error to Warning

    •  

       

  4. After this change, SAP will allow you to update the fiscal year variant.

    Important Reminder

    Changing the fiscal year variant is a high‑risk activity. Before and after the change, make sure to:

    • Test all end‑to‑end business processes

    • Validate all integrations (especially external systems)

    • Check for any data inconsistencies

    • Confirm that reporting works correctly

    • Ensure no postings behave differently

    Only move forward once everything is fully tested and approved.

entry.title: Anlagenbuchhaltung Restbuchwert von 1 Cent in der Anlage
entry.content:
in der Anlagenbuchhaltung ist folgender Sachverhalt aufgetreten. 
Eine Anlage mit Anschaffungswert 1950,01 Euro wurde über 10 Jahre abgeschrieben. Die Afa betrug jährlich 195,00 Euro. Mit dem 31.12.2024 wäre die Anlage in voller Höhe abgeschrieben gewesen. 
Afa-Beginn war der 01.01.2015. Allerdings wird jetzt ein Restbuchwert von 1 Cent auf der Anlage ausgewiesen, was eigentlich nicht sein sollte. Ein Erinnerungswert (von 1 Cent) ist für die Anlagenklasse nicht hinterlegt. Für das neue GJ 2025 wird auch keine keine weitere Afa-Buchung für den Abschreibungslauf ausgewiesen. Eigentlich hätte im Afa-Lauf 12/2024 im letzten Monat ein Betrag 16,01 Euro als Abschreibungswert gebucht werden müssen. Es wurden aber nur 16,00 Euro gebucht. 

Eine mögliche Ursache könnte hierfür in den Einstellungen zum Abschreibungsschlüssel und hier speziell zu den Rundungsregeln liegen. 

Bei einer anderen Anlage wird ein Betrag von 3,12 Euro als Abschreibung im letzten Afa-Lauf entsprechend ausgewiesen. Siehe Dokumentation. 

Ich bitte zu prüfen, wo hier die möglich Fehlerursache liegt, denn eigentlich hätte die Anlage keinen Restbuchwert mehr ausweisen dürfen.

Aufgrund des Jahresabschlusses und der anstehenden Prüfung der Jahresrechnung, sollte zumindest die Fehlerursache bekannt sein, daher bitte ich um eine zeitnahe Prüfung. Danke.
